image.altText: A map of Australia with multiple curving orange lines crossing it in different directions.

items.synopsis: Hundreds of Chinese satellites are currently passing over Australia collecting intelligence on military training activities involving the United States and other regional partners, according to commercial space data obtained by the ABC.

title.children: China deploys swarm of satellites to monitor military exercises in Australia

image.altText: Roof tops of houses

items.synopsis: Labor has reactivated its Help to Buy scheme, which means you can move into a "home" with just a 2 per cent deposit.

title.children: The federal government will offer some people the chance to buy a home with a 2pc deposit. Here's how it works

image.altText: Rosa Ansaldo behind the counter at her fruit shop.

title.children: Rosa's been selling produce at the Queen Victoria Market for decades, but now she fears for its future

image.altText: An overview of some vegetables including cherry tomatoes, button mushrooms, green  beans and yellow capsicum

items.synopsis: The suspected mushroom-poisoning deaths in Victoria of three people following a lunch has put a focus on the potential consequences of eating the wrong thing. Here's what food safety experts want you to know about food poisoning.

title.children: What you should know about the 'danger zone' for food poisoning

image.altText: A woman looks into the camera and smiles slightly.

items.synopsis: It's legal for one law firm to represent both sides of a real estate transaction but legal experts warn it can make navigating conflict difficult.

title.children: When Christine sold her home, the buyer used the same law firm. Things soon became 'very sticky'

image.altText: A smiling young boy with fair hair sits among giant plastic blocks of chocolate.

items.synopsis: Nicholas Henry died in 2021 after he was bashed and stabbed eight times in Morwell, Victoria. Three of those involved have been sentenced in the Supreme Court, but Mr Henry's sister says it "doesn't feel like justice".

title.children: 'How can this be real?' Sister in disbelief that killers who 'hunted down' defenceless brother could be free in three years

image.altText: A hazy red sky over federation square full of people

items.synopsis: Melbourne's Federation Square has been axed as a live site for the remainder of the Women's World Cup due to dozens of flares being let off within the capacity crowd there during Wednesday night's semifinal.

title.children: Federation Square axed as Women's World Cup live site

image.altText: A male politican in a blue suit and white tie, speaking at a lecturn in front of a sign that reads 'working for Australia'

items.synopsis: Labor is less than halfway into its first term, but Anthony Albanese knows if he leads a short-term government, what it achieves can be quickly negated. His message to delegates at the national conference is "be patient", writes Michelle Grattan.

title.children: Anthony Albanese had one clear message for delegates at Labor's national conference

image.altText: Small shrubs planted in red dirt.

items.synopsis: Experts are warning Australia's most popular carbon credit scheme, which pays landholders to allow forests to regenerate, is not performing to standard.

title.children: 'Performing badly': Experts warn of negative impacts of popular carbon offset scheme

image.altText: Close up of Britney Spears in a dress and necklace standing next to Sam Asghari in a suit and tie. Other people walk behind them

items.synopsis: This morning's news, as it happens.

title.children: Britney Spears's husband Sam Asghari files for divorce. The latest news with The Loop

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: In news just in, lawyers for former US president Donald Trump have proposed an April, 2026 date for the start of his criminal trial. It relates to the case in Washington charging the former president with conspiring to overturn the results of the 2020 election. The suggested date is a dramatic counter to the Justice Department’s recommendation last week of January 2. US District Judge Tanya Chutkan is expected to set the date during a court hearing scheduled for August 28.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Trump's lawyers propose 2026 trial date in election case

children.content: In news just in, lawyers for former US president
Donald Trump
have proposed an April, 2026 date for the start of his criminal trial.
It relates to the case in Washington charging the former president with conspiring to overturn the results
of the 2020 election.
The suggested date is a dramatic counter to the Justice Department’s recommendation last week of January 2.
US District Judge Tanya Chutkan is expected to set the date during a court hearing scheduled for August 28.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: By North America correspondent Barbara Miller Authorities in the US state of Georgia are investigating online threats against the jurors who voted this week to indict Donald Trump and 18 others over an alleged conspiracy to overturn the 2020 presidential election results. Unlike in federal and many other state cases, the names of those jurors are listed in the indictment, which has reportedly led to doxing. In a statement, the Fulton County Sheriff’s office says it "is aware that personal information of members of the Fulton County Grand Jury is being shared on various platforms". The Sheriff’s office says the matter is being taken "very seriously" and it’s working to track down the origins of the threats. Some online posts reportedly suggested jurors were harassed, but it’s not clear whether that has actually happened. It all adds to the tension around Fulton County, Atlanta, where Trump and his co-defendants have been given until the end of next week to appear at the Rice Street jail to be booked in the case, which is expected to involve the former president having his mugshot taken.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Threats have reportedly been made against jurors who voted to indict Donald Trump in Georgia

children.content: By North America correspondent Barbara Miller

Authorities in the US state of Georgia are investigating online threats against the jurors who voted this week to indict Donald Trump and 18 others over an alleged conspiracy to overturn the 2020 presidential election results.
Unlike in federal and many other state cases,
the names of those jurors are listed in the indictment, which has reportedly led to doxing.

props.alt: A group of police and security personel standing outside of a courthouse

children.content: (AP: Ben Gray)
In a statement, the Fulton County Sheriff’s office says it "is aware that personal information of members of the Fulton County Grand Jury is being shared on various platforms".
The Sheriff’s office says the matter is being taken "very seriously" and it’s working to track down the origins of the threats.
Some online posts reportedly suggested jurors were harassed, but it’s not clear whether that has actually happened.

It all adds to the tension around Fulton County, Atlanta, where Trump and his co-defendants have been given until the end of next week to appear at the Rice Street jail to be booked in the case, which is expected to involve the former president having his mugshot taken.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Football Australia is hoping the excitement behind the Matildas at the Women's World Cup will put Australia in a strong position to host other upcoming major football events. AAP reports Football Australia is set to challenge Saudi Arabia for hosting rights to the 2026 Women's Asian Cup. The organisation has also been ambitious in its desire to bid for hosting rights to the men's World Cup in 2034 and the revamped Club World Cup in 2029. But the Women's Asian Cup in 2026 looms as a much more attainable proposition. Football Australia CEO James Johnson tells AAP: "(A successful bid) would extend this window for a major growth in the Australian game which is really being turbocharged by the women's game. "There's a lot of logic for that bid, it's calculated because women's football is growing rapidly around the world and in particular in Australia. "We've seen the success of the Matildas at this World Cup and we know when we hosted the Asian Cup in 2015 that was a big success. "We're taking it seriously and we're working with state and federal governments to make sure we have the right backing to get that over the line."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: As the Matildas prepare for Sweden, Football Australia prepares to bid for more local events

props.alt: Sam Kerr smiles and gives a thumbs up while walking into the changerooms at a football stadium. Fans in the stands behind clapping

children.content: (Getty Images: FIFA/Maddie Meyer)
Football Australia is hoping the excitement behind the Matildas at the Women's World Cup will put Australia in a strong position to host other upcoming major football events.
AAP reports Football Australia is set to challenge Saudi Arabia for hosting rights to the 2026 Women's Asian Cup.
The organisation has also been ambitious in its desire to bid for hosting rights to the men's World Cup in 2034 and the revamped Club World Cup in 2029.
But the Women's Asian Cup in 2026 looms as a much more attainable proposition.
Football Australia CEO James Johnson tells AAP:
"(A successful bid) would extend this window for a major growth in the Australian game which is really being turbocharged by the women's game.
"There's a lot of logic for that bid, it's calculated because women's football is growing rapidly around the world and in particular in Australia.
"We've seen the success of the Matildas at this World Cup and we know when we hosted the Asian Cup in 2015 that was a big success.
"We're taking it seriously and we're working with state and federal governments to make sure we have the right backing to get that over the line."

image.altText: Michael Parkinson

items.synopsis: It's hard to believe there was anyone Sir Michael Parkinson hadn't spoken to during his glittering decades-long media career — but last year, he said there was one more interview he'd like to do.

title.children: 'We're in the palm of his hand': The man Michael Parkinson wanted to interview last year

image.altText: Several boats are moored at a marina, with palm trees in the background and a shed on the shore

items.synopsis: When two boats set off towards an Indonesian island for a birthday surfing trip, none of those on board could have predicted the next few days. Here's how the survivors managed more than 36 hours at sea.

title.children: 'Alright everybody get the f out!': How a split-second decision may have saved four Australians

image.altText: Sun setting through a line of transmission towers

items.synopsis: Across Australia, governments have set ambitious goals for turning their power systems green. But a decision to keep a coal plant running longer suggests the rhetoric is not matched by the reality.

title.children: 'Reality catching up with rhetoric' as coal-fired closure delayed

image.altText: A grinning man smiles as he looks down at his smiling bride, with her white veil pulled back over her head.

items.synopsis: China's infamous censors are methodical about keeping the country's closed internet free from information that the ruling Communist Party does not want its citizens seeing, but a new report from Human Rights Watch finds racist content on the Chinese internet targeting black people has become common.

title.children: Human Rights Watch calls on Beijing to remove racist content from Chinese internet

image.altText: Chinese flags near the logo Evergrande Centre in Shanghai, China, on September 24, 2021.

items.synopsis: China's second-largest property developer, the embattled China Evergrande Group, has filed for Chapter 15 bankruptcy protection in New York, while the Australian sharemarket is set to open lower on Friday. Follow live.

title.children: China Evergrande files for bankruptcy protection in US, ASX to follow Wall Street's pessimism and open lower

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: If you cast your mind back to 2021, you might recall SpaceX CEO Elon Musk announcing his company had acquired an undisclosed amount of Bitcoin, after Musk's other company Tesla announced it had bought $US1.5 billion worth of the cryptocurrency. At the time, Musk's endorsement of Bitcoin sent the price surging, past $US44,000. Now the Wall Street Journal is reporting that SpaceX had $US373 million worth of Bitcoin in 2021 and 2022, but has since sold it — and it's this report that has caused the cryptocurrency to drop substantially this morning. It's unclear though exactly when SpaceX might have sold its Bitcoin. (For what it's worth, neither SpaceX nor Elon Musk have commented on the report.)
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Why did Bitcoin plunge today? It's all to do with Elon Musk (and SpaceX)

children.content: If you cast your mind back to 2021, you might recall
SpaceX CEO Elon Musk
announcing his company had acquired an undisclosed amount of Bitcoin, after Musk's other company Tesla announced it had bought
$US1.5 billion
worth of the cryptocurrency.
At the time, Musk's endorsement of Bitcoin sent the price surging, past $US44,000.
Now the
Wall Street Journal
is reporting that SpaceX had
$US373 million worth of Bitcoin in 2021 and 2022, but has since sold it
— and it's this report that has caused the cryptocurrency to drop substantially this morning.
It's unclear though exactly when SpaceX might have sold its Bitcoin.
(For what it's worth, neither SpaceX nor Elon Musk have commented on the report.)

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Aussie dollar is going through quite the rollercoaster lately, but analysts at NAB have described it as a "doom loop", where one negative movement is cycling through the currency markets. For the unfamiliar, "doom loop" or ("urban doom loop") was coined by a professor at Colombia University to describe the downward spiral some cities are facing — like San Francisco, which is in the midst of an opioid crisis, high housing costs, and tech boom all at once. In layman's terms, it's a cycle of one negative condition feeding another negative condition, which feeds another negative condition, and so it goes. But NAB's head of markets, Ray Attrill, has plagiarised the term (his words, not mine) to describe what's currently happening in currency markets. He explained that the "ongoing appreciation" of the US dollar and Japan yen — which hit a new high of ¥146.56 overnight — is causing an aversion from China when it comes to the Chinese yuan and Japanese yen exchange rate (which is especially relevant given China and Japan are competing over manufacturing high-end goods like electric vehicles). Comparatively, the US dollar and Chinese yuan exchange rate hit its highest level since November 3 overnight, and that's ricocheted throughout the Asia-Pacific. It's that flow on effect that caused the NZ dollar to plummet to 59.03 US cents overnight, and sending the Aussie dollar down to 63 US cents (the lowest for both currencies since early November). Given the additional uncertainties China's economy is facing, we can expect to see this loop to continue for a while yet.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Australia's declining dollar has found itself in a 'doom loop'

"doom loop"

currency markets

In layman's terms, it's

But

head of markets, Ray Attrill
, has plagiarised the term (his words, not mine) to describe what's currently happening in currency markets.
He explained that the "ongoing appreciation" of the US dollar and Japan yen — which hit a new high of ¥146.56 overnight —
is causing an aversion from China
when it comes to the Chinese yuan and Japanese yen exchange rate (which is especially relevant given China and Japan are competing over manufacturing high-end goods like electric vehicles).
Comparatively, the

Aussie dollar down to 63 US cents
(the lowest for both currencies since early November).
Given the additional uncertainties China's economy is facing, we can expect to see this loop to continue for a while yet.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Latitude Financial has posted its half-yearly results to June 30 on the ASX this morning, with its CEO Bob Belan describing the first six months of the year "amongst the most challenging in Latitude's history". Back in March, the company disclosed it had been the target of a cyber attack that saw millions of Australians have their personal data compromised, and is considered to be one of the largest cyber breaches in Australian history. Latitude is reporting a statutory loss (after tax) of $98.2 million, which includes $76 million of "pre-tax costs and provisions relating to the March cyber incident". Its cash profit is also down 88% to $7 million. Compared to last year, cash net profit after tax came in at $86 million. In an investor presentation, Belan noted that the "cyber disruption" impacted their the volume of sales, but it is slowly picking back up. It noted that before the cyber attack in January and February, its volume was up 12.5%, and is down 3% year on year — but as of June this year, volume has returned to June 2022 levels. Latitude also notes that while it is now focused on safely restoring business operations, significant financial risks remain because of the cyber attack, including: Regulatory fines Legal claims and/or class actions Technology review The company has also told investors there will be no first-half dividend.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Latitude Financial posts half-yearly $98m loss after cyber hack in March

children.content: Latitude Financial
has posted its half-yearly results to June 30 on the ASX this morning, with its CEO Bob Belan describing the first six months of the year
"amongst the most challenging in Latitude's history"
Back in March, the company disclosed it had been the target of a cyber attack that saw millions of Australians have their personal data compromised, and is considered to be
one of the largest cyber breaches in Australian history
Latitude is reporting a statutory loss (after tax) of $98.2 million
, which includes $76 million of "pre-tax costs and provisions relating to the March cyber incident".
Its
cash profit is also down 88% to $7 million
. Compared to last year, cash net profit after tax came in at $86 million.
In an investor presentation, Belan noted that the "cyber disruption" impacted their the volume of sales, but it is slowly picking back up.
It noted that before the cyber attack in January and February, its volume was up 12.5%, and is down 3% year on year — but as of June this year, volume has returned to June 2022 levels.
Latitude also notes that while it is now focused on safely restoring business operations,
significant financial risks remain because of the cyber attack
, including:
Regulatory fines
Legal claims and/or class actions
Technology review
The company has also told investors there will be no first-half dividend.

image.altText: Offshore wind turbines in the ocean, with a blue sky overhead.

title.children: Gippsland port set to play a big role in the operations of offshore wind project

title.children: Australia is spending $4.77 billion on foreign aid this year, but is it enough?

image.altText: a woman looks directly at the camera. She has long brown hair and is wearing a black top.

items.synopsis: Kobie Parfitt feared for her life days before she was killed by her friend Shannon Jeffrey, the Supreme Court in Melbourne heard. Jeffrey had only been out of prison for less than two weeks when Ms Parfitt was killed.

title.children: Mother of four killed by friend who dumped body down a mineshaft

image.altText: A younger and older portrait of a man.

title.children: Our Vietnam War was more than the hundreds killed — the aftermath was confronting for the 60,000 who served

image.altText: Maatsuyker island lighthouse, Tasmania

items.synopsis: If you've ever been for a dip in the ocean, you know the warmth of the water can vary wildly. On a grand scale, sea surface temperatures also play a significant role in the weather around you, writes the Bureau of Meteorology's Matthew Thomas.

title.children: Above and below the sea, how do ocean temperatures influence Tasmania's weather?

image.altText: A submarine is seen on the surface of the water in front of mountains and clear skies.

title.children: Government braces for 'difficult' debate on AUKUS at labor conference

image.altText: Two women and a man at a table, tasting wine.

title.children: Australia's best wines named, overall winner declared 'shoulder to shoulder' with world's finest

image.altText: Afghanistan women's soccer team player Mursal Sadat standing on the field looking at the the camera

items.synopsis: Activists are calling on FIFA to grant the team official recognition, as Afghanistan's men's national soccer team continues to be recognised.

image.altText: Female in yellow soccer jersey standing next to the goalposts.

image.altText: A young man stands with an older woman in front of microphones.

title.children: 'Heroic' John Hancock forced to drive with old brake pads amid pressure from billionaire mother, court told

image.altText: Owen Farrell stands with his hands on his hips

title.children: England's skipper should have been banned for six weeks, but World Rugby 'critically undermined' its own guidelines

image.altText: Sam Williamson bursts out of the water wearing an Australian gold swimming cap

items.synopsis: Swimming Australia calls a special general meeting to avoid being kicked out of the sport's global governing body due to perceived governance issues.

title.children: Swimming Australia threatened with expulsion from World Aquatics

image.altText: Rachel Zegler stands and smiles at a press event.

items.synopsis: Resurfaced comments made by actress Rachel Zegler about her upcoming live-action remake of Disney's Snow White spark outrage online.

title.children: 'The original came out in 1937, and evidently so': Actress Rachel Zegler's Snow White interview goes viral
